misconceptions.name: Does not read the grade from user input
misconceptions.description: The program never reads a numeric grade (0–100) from the user; instead it reads four doubles for point coordinates and then uses a hard-coded int grade = 85. This fails the rubric requirement to read the grade from input. Total rubric score: 0/5. Overall feedback: Your program mostly implements a distance calculator and only partially attempts the grade logic; re-read the problem and focus the code on reading a single grade and mapping it to the correct letter output.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that it is acceptable to hard-code the test grade value (e.g., 85) while still reading other, unrelated inputs from the user.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should prompt for and read exactly one numeric grade value from the user (e.g., with nextInt or nextDouble) and then base all grade calculations on that input, not on a hard-coded constant.
symptoms: Scanner is used to read x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single grade.
The grade variable is assigned a fixed value of 85 rather than being read from input.
There is no prompt like "Enter grade:" and no input call associated with the grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between the example/sample run value (85) and the need to accept arbitrary user input for the grade.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Remove the coordinate inputs and instead prompt the user with "Enter grade:" and read a single numeric value into grade using the Scanner, then use that value in your conditional checks.
related_concepts: Reading input from the keyboard with Scanner
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The only grade value in the code is int grade = 85 and there is no input operation for a grade, while multiple unrelated doubles are read.

evidence.note: Rubric: Reading numeric grade input — Score 0/1. The code reads coordinates instead of a grade and then hard-codes grade to 85.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Incomplete and partially implemented ranges for A and B
misconceptions.description: Only the B range is implemented (80–89) and there is no condition for A (90–100), so the rubric requirement for correct Boolean ranges for both A and B is not met.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student seems to believe that implementing only the B range condition is sufficient, possibly assuming that the example grade (85) is the only case needed.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should include conditional checks that correctly cover both A (90–100) and B (80–89) ranges, typically using >= and <= / < with a proper if/else-if structure.
symptoms: There is an if condition for grade between 80 and 90, but none for 90–100.
Grades in the A range would produce no letter grade output.
Use of a single & operator with two comparisons, though it still evaluates as a Boolean AND here.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely focused on matching the sample input of 85 and did not generalize the solution to all specified ranges.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add a condition for A, such as if (grade >= 90 && grade <= 100) { System.out.println("Letter grade: A"); }, and use else-if for B with the correct bounds (80–89).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The only condition checks grade >= 80 & grade < 90; no references to 90–100 or A appear anywhere.

evidence.note: Rubric: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B — Score 0/1. Only B (80–89) is implemented; A (90–100) is missing.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for C and D
misconceptions.name: Missing ranges for C and D grades
misconceptions.description: There are no conditions at all for C (70–79) or D (60–69), so these middle ranges are never classified and the rubric requirement is not satisfied.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to ignore or overlook the need to handle C and D ranges, perhaps thinking only B (or the sample grade) needs explicit handling.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should include Boolean conditions that correctly capture the C (70–79) and D (60–69) ranges so that every possible grade receives the appropriate letter.
symptoms: No numeric constants 60, 69, 70, or 79 appear in the code.
No branches exist for printing C or D.
Grades in these ranges would produce no letter grade output at all.
misconceptions.root_cause: Incomplete translation of the grade scale specification into code; only part of the required ranges were implemented.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Extend the conditional chain with else-if blocks: else if (grade >= 70 && grade < 80) { ...C... } and else if (grade >= 60 && grade < 70) { ...D... }.
related_concepts: Coverage of all specified input ranges
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code has zero references to C or D grades or to the 60–79 numeric ranges.

evidence.note: Rubric: Correct Boolean ranges for C and D — Score 0/1. No additional conditions exist for 70–79 (C) or 60–69 (D).

misconceptions.name: No default case for F (grades below 60)
misconceptions.description: The program has a single if condition for B-range grades and no else or catch-all branch, so F grades (below 60) and any other unhandled grades produce no output instead of 'F'.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student seems to believe that only explicitly coded ranges need handling and that failing to meet a condition does not require a specific default branch.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: There should be a default or else branch (or an explicit < 60 condition) to print an F when the grade is below 60 or otherwise not in A–D ranges.
symptoms: Only one if statement without else or else-if to handle remaining cases.
No code path that prints 'F' or handles grades below 60.
Grades outside 80–89 simply result in no letter grade output.
misconceptions.root_cause: Lack of awareness that all input ranges must be covered, with a final else or explicit F condition for remaining grades.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After handling A–D with if/else-if blocks, add a final else { System.out.println("Letter grade: F"); } to cover grades below 60 and any uncaptured values.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is exactly one if condition and no else branch; F is never mentioned.

evidence.note: Rubric: Correct handling of F (default/else) — Score 0/1. No else or F-handling branch exists.

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Incorrect and incomplete letter-grade output mapping
misconceptions.description: The program outputs the text 'Grade is in the B range.' instead of 'Letter grade: B' and does not print any output for A, C, D, or F ranges, so the mapping from ranges to the specified letter outputs is incorrect and incomplete.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that describing the range in words ("in the B range") is acceptable and that only B requires explicit output.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For each numeric range (A, B, C, D, F), the program should print exactly the letter in the required format, e.g., 'Letter grade: B', ensuring that all possible grades produce the correct letter.
symptoms: The output string does not match the required 'Letter grade: X' format.
Only B has any associated print statement; there are no outputs for A, C, D, or F.
The initial prompts and outputs refer to point distance rather than grading.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misreading or partially implementing the output specification, and mixing in unrelated output from a different problem (distance between two points).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change the print statements to match the exact required format, e.g., System.out.println("Letter grade: B"); and add similar lines for A, C, D, and F after computing the correct range for the entered grade.
related_concepts: Mapping condition results to user-friendly messages
Avoiding leftover code from other problems
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The only grade-related output is 'Grade is in the B range.' and there are several lines about point distance, none about letter grades A/C/D/F.

evidence.note: Rubric: Mapping each range to correct letter output — Score 0/1. Output refers to distance and then only prints 'Grade is in the B range.' instead of 'Letter grade: B' and lacks outputs for other ranges.

No actual user interaction occurs for grade entry
Output is always the same regardless of what the user enters

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Incorrect boolean operator - using & instead of &&
misconceptions.description: The student uses the bitwise AND operator `&` instead of the logical AND operator `&&` in the conditional statement. While this may work in some cases, it is semantically incorrect for boolean logic.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that `&` and `&&` are interchangeable for boolean conditions.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Use `&&` (logical AND) for boolean conditions, not `&` (bitwise AND). The `&` operator performs bitwise operations and evaluates both sides even if the left side is false, while `&&` short-circuits and is the standard for boolean logic.
symptoms: Code uses bitwise operator instead of logical operator
Potential performance issue from lack of short-circuit evaluation
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between bitwise operators (`&`, `|`) and logical operators (`&&`, `||`).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change `&` to `&&` in the condition: `if(grade>=80 && grade<90)`
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The use of `&` instead of `&&` is explicitly visible in the code. While this may technically work for boolean values in Java, it's the wrong operator semantically.

evidence.snippet: if(grade>=80 & grade<90){
evidence.note: Uses bitwise AND operator `&` instead of logical AND operator `&&` for the boolean condition.

misconceptions.name: Hardcoding grade instead of reading from user
misconceptions.description: The program never reads a numeric grade from the user; instead it hardcodes the grade value in a variable while reading unrelated coordinate inputs. This suggests confusion between using variables for fixed test data and actually obtaining the required input from the keyboard.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can just assign a specific grade value (e.g., 85) to a variable instead of reading the grade from the user, and still satisfy the requirement to process a grade.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this task, the program must prompt for and read the grade value the user types (e.g., using Scanner and nextInt or nextDouble) and then base the letter-grade logic on that input, not on a hardcoded constant.

Grade is set with a literal value (85) rather than read from Scanner
Changing the user’s input does not change the grade that is evaluated
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely reusing code from a distance-calculation problem without adapting input handling, and a misunderstanding that testing with a fixed value is equivalent to reading required user input.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Remove the coordinate input and distance calculation; instead prompt with something like "Enter grade:" and use input.nextInt() (or nextDouble()) to read the numeric grade into the grade variable before applying the grading logic.
related_concepts: Using Scanner to read user input
Difference between literals and runtime input
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence because the only grade-related value is a literal assignment and Scanner is used exclusively for unrelated coordinate inputs.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Using & instead of && in boolean condition
misconceptions.description: The student uses the single ampersand & operator in a boolean if condition instead of the conventional short-circuit && operator, indicating a possible confusion between bitwise and logical conjunction.
misconceptions.student_belief: The & operator can be used interchangeably with && for combining boolean conditions in if statements.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java, && is the standard logical AND operator with short-circuit behavior for boolean expressions, while & is primarily a bitwise operator that, when used with booleans, evaluates both sides and is less idiomatic.
symptoms: Condition for B range uses & instead of &&
Non-short-circuit operation is used where a normal logical AND is expected
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between operators from other contexts (e.g., bitwise operations or other languages) and Java’s boolean logic operators.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace & with && in boolean conditions combining relational checks, and review the difference between bitwise (&) and logical (&&) operators in Java.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student explicitly uses & between two boolean comparisons in an if condition, a common beginner confusion; while it works here, it reveals a likely misunderstanding of operator roles.

evidence.note: The boolean condition uses & instead of the more appropriate && operator when combining grade>=80 and grade<90.
